The beneficial effect of Senator Hale's paciHc diplomacy as exercised in yesterday's debate was clearly observable to day, and out cf the confusion of thought which was prevalent In many quarters at the close of yesterday's session there has crystallized a be lief that the adoption of the resolution whirh Mr

Hale's tactics Is the determination of Sen ator Lodge to withdraw his motion to lay the Bacon resolution on the table a course which, while it seemed imperative because of the dan ger of misleading the Colombians, would In evitably have elicited acrimonious- opposition from the Democrats

The Bacon and Hale resolutions will now go to the Committee on Foreign Relation, where they will doubtless be made the subject of consider able debate, and It Is by no mean 3 unlikely that the result will be the reporting of a resolution along the lines suggested by Mr

Such a resolution would undoubtedly afford a bridge whereby a number of Democratic Sen ators could cross the objections to which they are already committed, and several have pri vately expressed the hope that the Repul leans would give them such an opportunity

Another consideration which will be brought to the attention of the committee will be the possible assistance which such a resolution might afford to the Colombian leaders, who thoroughly appreciate the futility of resisting the course of events, but are experiencing diffi culty in restraining their followers

Secretary Hay has already tendered the good offices of the United States In the disagreement between the Republic of Panama and Colombia, and from Etrlctly logical point of view the Hale resolution is unnecessary, but as a pure matter of expedi ency, which might prove a soothing application to the Colombians, who are stricken with re morse at their own injudicious course, it might have a beneficial effect on the situation, and there are a number of Senators who will advo cate its adoption on that ground

Ratifications Exchanged and Presi dent's Proclamation Issued

Ratifications of the com mercial treaty between the United States and China were exchanged at the State Department to-day by Secretary Hay and Sir Chentung Liang-Cheng, the Chinese Minister here, and lata this afternoon President Roossveit issued the following proclamation, putting the treaty Into effect By the President of the United States of Amer ica

A Proclamation Whereas, A treaty and three annexes be tween Urn United States of America and China to extend further the commercial relations be tween them and otherwise to promote the in terests of the people of the two countries were concluded and signed at Shanghai, In the Eng lish and Chinese languages, on the Bth day of October, 1900, the original of the English text of which treaty and annexes la, word for word, as follows Here is published the text of the- treaty

And whereas, The said treaty and annexes had been duly ratified on both parts, and the ratifications cf the two governments were ex changed In the dry of Washington, on the 13th day of January, 1004 Now, therefore, be it known that I, Theodore Roosevelt, President of the United States of America, have caused the said treaty and an nexes to be made public, to the end that the same and every article and clause thereof may be observed and fulfilled with good faith by the United States and the citizens thereof
I have hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the United States to be affixed
Done at the city of Washington, this 13th day of January, in the year of Our Lord, 1904, and of the Independence of the United States the one hundred and twenty-eighth
The following statement regarding the treaty wa3 Issued by the State Department The treaty which will go Into effect In a day or so
through the exchange of ratifications ef fected to-day, and by Its promulgation by the President of the United States, is tha result of nearly a year and a half's negotiation

Although relating in Its principal provisions to questions of commerce and navigation, removing restric tions which have hampered them both in China, it also treats of a number of questions of great importance to the people of the two countries

It defines the rights and privileges of the diplomatic and consular officers and of American citizens, especially missionaries, resid ing China, and Insures the latter enjoyment of rights which they have only had In the past practically by toleration
In suring them a fair degree of protection in Cblna a thing which they have had very little of In the past

Perhaps the provision of the treaty which In terests most the public is the opening of two new localities In Manchuria to foreign trade the city of Moukden and the town of An- Tung, or Shao, as it is frequently called, on the Yalu River

It Is to be noted In this connec tion that the Japanese and Chinese treaty, the ratifications of which were exchanged yester day at Peking, secures also to lnternationil trade the opening of the port of Tatung Kou
about thirteen miles below An-Tung, and at the mouth of the Yalu

It Is highly probable that the presence in these localities at an early date of American consular officers and those of other nationalities for all the nations having treaties with China acquire by our treaty, and that with Japan, the right to establish consulates at these placeswill greatly tend to the establishment of order In this much disturbed border land of China, and will powerfully contribute toward lnsurinp the principles of the open door
to which this country stands Irrevocably comm't well as aiding In insuring the lntesrrlty r- Chtaw and Its administrative control over its Manchurian provinces
The exchange of ratifications took place at the State Department by appointment at 11 o'clock
The Chinese Minister was accompanied by his secretary
Conger had informed the department that thf Chinese government placed an exchange copy of the treaty In h
This is held to be equivalent to the delivery of the document to the United States government as required by the treaty itself
So Secretary Hay and the Chinese Minister joined to-day In the signature of the protocol, reciting the fact that ratifications had been exchanged
The Chinese Minister will receive a copy of the treaty by the State Department, which he will forward to his government for deposit In the imperial archives In Peking, and when Mr
Congers copy reaches Washington It will be placed in the State Department Library
The treaty is now an accomplished fact, and ft remains only to appoint the necessary con sqls at Moukden and An-Tung
Their names will bo sent to the Senate as soon as Congress makes provision for their salary, which the State De partment hopes will be done speedily
It is re garded as extremely desirable that such rights ps the United States has acaulred in Manchuria
as to China shall be fully established and as serted in advance of any possible war that might affect that vast territory to the extent of a change of sovereignty

-ho has been In elos,e communica tion with the French government relative to the Russo-Japanese situation, said to-day that a Ftrong feeling existed In the highest offtvlal quar ters that Japan had gradually enlarged her de mands until those of to-day went considerably beyond those first presented

1 the official view that Japan's present de mands for the integrity of China and full recog nition of Chinese authority uver Manchuria rep resent an important advance over the early rep resentations

British Officials Sure That fftJttfa Will Xot Break Treaty
1n the opinion of the British government the end of this week does not mark any change In the Far Eastern crisis, which more than ever keeps diplomatic circles in Lon don in a state of anxiety

The latest and, if it had been true, the most serious statement namely, that Russia intended to risk sending her Black Sea fleet through the Dardanelles received to-day a positive denial from the Foreign Office
the Japanese Minister, visited Downing Street this afternoon, nnd was told that after making minute Inquiries the British authorities were convinced that the report was unfounded
Baron Hayashi and the Foreign Office had no information
Not even the Czar's pacific utterances, however, can dis pel the fear which pervades British officials that Russia will not yield
King Edward continues to use his personal Influence to an almost un precedented extent to persuade the Czar to maintain peace, but the King's ministers appear to have practically given up hope that n
resort to arms can be averted, though even the most pessimistic persons do not look for nny culmina tion of the crisis within three weeks

How determined Japan is to face all the even tualities can be judged from the fact that she is negotiating in England for the construct of four battleships, not two battleship, as pre viously reported
The negotiations are not yet dosed, but the contract is likely to be taken up by the largest English firm within a week
The firm In question Kays that it is satisfied Japan is able to carry on a possible war long enough to pay for and use the vessels, which necessarily could not be ready under two years

In Rome Western and Southern States this policy baa been Increas ingly pursued within the h-v few years, and official reports of Its success are not contra dicted by other testimony

During the last summer the experiment was made in Schenec tfldy County, to the satisfaction of the local authorities, -vre learn from an interesting ac ccunt of it in The Municipal Journal and En gineer

After an investigation of the subject by a committee of the Board of Supervisors, a con tract was made with the town of Glenve for the macadamizing of a particularly bad piece of road, and in the course of seven mouths, with an average force of twenty prisoners from the county Jail, two and a half miles were put into excellent condition
The specifications pre scribed by the State where State aid is fur nished ere strictly followed, but the county and town bore all the expense, which, how ever, wi not g
One guard to eight prisoners was found to be enough, the men, as a rule, were cheerful and industrious, end the citizens suffered no annoyance or apprehension
Occa sionally a convict was Indisposed to exert him self, but he 6Oin changed his mind after being put on short rations
It is not work In which craftsmen would dislike to 6oe convicts employed

Undoubtedly the plan Is subject to some objections, and it Is possible that they might prove more serious In this State than they have been found to be in the Yest and South, though we see no reason to accept that hypothesis

In his address to college men at the reception of the Brooklyn Tnlversity Club, on Friday evening, President Eliot took up a question which has been before discussed by other lead ers of public opinion, and came to the same conclusion, that true American liberty is gravely menaced by associations of employers on the one hand and employes on the other

His ad mirable and impreHslve utterance should have great Influence In arousing educated men to the sinister meaning of the present day drift to grind individual liberty and crush out individ ual opportunity between the upper and nether millstones of Intolerant and exclusive organ izations

The Brooklyn men who heard President Eliot's calm, clear and convincing ex position of the present state of affairs must have bans aroused to a new appreciation of the gravity of the task which they have to preserve freedom, a task which, in spite of warnings, they and other happy-go-lucky Americans are prone to estimate lightly
It is somewhat startling to find President Eliot quietly announcing, not as a figure of speech, but v
an actual simple fact, that In Boston to-day there Is less liberty than there was in 177
Our ancestors fought King George because he would not give them enough liberty in that year

Less liberty for their posterity now In Boston than when they r-roltd against a petty tax on tea, which inter fered with nobody's comfort or ability to earn a living' where and as he chose Yet, If we con sider, we shall pee that the statement is liter ally true

King George never dreamed of such interference with the colonists at the free citi zens of the United States and the common wealth of Massachusetts and of every other commonwealth in th land dally endure at the hands of Irresponsible combinations which have usurped the power of telling them who may build their house and at what price, whom they may employ and at what wages
Between the tyrannical rule of the trust on the one hand and the labor union on the other, whether the two work in opposition or In harmony, the average citizen Is helpless

He Is subjected by them to extortion hln enn- Tenlence, his business, even his health and iife, are ruthlessly sacrificed to their prerogative for which they are more eelnsh, and more ambi tious, and more unscrupulous than King George ever was for th power and prestige of the British Crown
It Is time for educated mea and men of Colonial ancestry to awaka to th danger, and President Eliot performs a public service when he oses his grwt Influence wrer tbcai to work for the aafaguardlofrr
than the recovery Amprioan liberty from the despotism -whirl has grown up within our own borders

NNA ISSUES THE CALL NOTICE OF COXTEXTIOX
Senator Hanna, chair man of the Republican National Committee, ar rived in Washington to-day, and immediately Issued the call for the national convention

The expedition with which this matter was finally disposed of is conceded by prominent Republi cans to have bees due to the rumors to which the delay gave rise and to the forcible manner in which they were brought to the attention of the executive committee
Although the date of the call i later than on any occasion in the last quarter of a century, with the single exception of l v '

' when the call vas issued on January it having been cus tomary to issue it about December IS any dis position to criticize has given place to expres sions of gratification that the desired end is finally accomplished
Early in the day there was some comment on th facts that late last night the csslstant sec retary of the National Committee gave out an interview In which he attributed the delay to I
-k of Information concerning the manner of selecting delegates from the District of Colum bia thuftbe urn evening Senator Hanp
allKing the neces sity of Investigating Chicago hotel rates as one Of his reasons for postponing the
-all and the awe day Senator Scott, a member of the execu tive committee, ma'- 1 statement explaining that Mr
Hannu's ill health and preoccupation With private affairs had prevented action
The issue of the call will permit of the usual formalities in every State, and will enable the active workers to begin their prepara tions at once

The text f the call la as follows To Urn Republican Elector of the United State In accordance with established custom and in obedience to instructions of the national con vention of 1h, the Republican National Com

directs that a national convention of dele gated representatives of the Republican party be held at the city of Chicago, in the State of Illinois, for the purpose of nominating- candi dates for President sad Vice-President, to be voted for at the Presidential election on Tues day
November 8, 1901, and for the transaction of such other business as may properly come before it
and said convention shall assemble at 11 o'clock noon on Tuesday, the -Ist day of June, 1901 The Republican electors of the several States and Territories, the District of Columbia

Alaska and Indian Territory, and all other electors, without regard to asl political affiliations, who believe In the principles of the Republican party and indorse its policiies, are cordially Invited to unite under this call in the selection of candi dates for President and Vice-President

Said national convention shall consist of a number of delegates' at-large from each State equal to double the number of I'nited States Senators to which each State is entitled, and for each Representative-at-large in Congress, two delegates-at-large
From each Congressional district and the District of Columbia, two dele gates
-Mexico, Oklahoma and Hawaii and Indian Territory, six delegates
For each delegate elected to said convention an alternate delegate shall be elect ed to act In case of the absence of the delegate, such alternate delegate
All delegates shall be elected not less than thirty days before the meeting of the national convention

Delegates-at-large shall be elected by popular State and Territorial conventions, of which at least thirty days' notice shall have been published in some newspaper or newspa pers of general circulation in the respective States and Territories
The Congressional district delegates shall be elected by conventions called by the Congres sional Committee of each district

In the manner of nominating the candidate for Representative In Congress In said district, provided that in any Congressional District where there is no Repub lican Congressional Committee the Republican State Committee shall appoint from among the Republican residents in such district a commit tee for the purpose Of calling a district conven tion to elect delegates to represent said district
The election of delegates from the District of Columbia shall be held under the direction and supervision of an election board composed of Mr
The board shall have au thority to fix the date of such election and to arrange all details an 1 regulations Incident thereto, an
The Territorial delegates shall be elected In the manner of nominating candidates for Dole gates in Congress, and delegates from Alaska and Indian Territory shall be elected by popu lar convention

All notices of contests shall be submitted in writing, accompanied by a printed statement, setting forth the grounds of contest, which shall be Hied with the secretary of the national com mittee twenty days prior to the meeting of the national convention
Contests will be acted on by the national con vention in the order at the date of tiling of notk and statement with the secretary

FRANCHISE TAX ADVANCE Increased Valuation Will Raise Levy About One-third

-The action of the Board of Assessors of New-York City in greatly increas ing the assessed valuation of real estate in that municipality will materially affect the amount of special franchise taxes that corporations operating in that city will be required to pay ur

It is probable that their , assessments will be increased about one-third I Of course, this is dependent on a decision of j the United States Supreme Coi-rt sustaining the I decision of the Court of Appeals of this state

In the equalization of the valuation of real , estate in this State among the several counties I the State Board of Equalization has rated the valuation for New-York City at per cent that is, it has held that the local assessors val ued that class of property at 67 per cent of its actual or market value, in 1NT8 the local as sessors of New- York increased the total value of real estate from IU3MT
The Special Franchise Tax law provides that the value of the special franchises shall be j fixed by the State Board of Tax Commissioners j at full value
Under that i decision the assessments placed on franchises operated in New-York City will be reduced about one-thin
When the State Board of Equalization pre pares Its next equalization table the rate for New- York City 'will be increased in consequence of the Increased valuation made by the assessors of that city
It Is estimated that the next equal ization table will rate New-York at 75 instead of 67 per cent
Thus, in the readjustment of special franchise tax valuations in that city In the future the reduction will be about 25 in stead of 33 per cent

It is learned here to-day that the corporations of New- York City which are parties to the liti gation attacking the special franchise tax act in j the Federal Supreme Court are practically tha i enly large corporations which have not yet paid their taxes under the law

The exact figures cannot be ascertained, because the j amount due depends not only on the assessment j made, but also on reductions to be made under i the Court of Appeals decision and the additions I for Interest
In most up-State counties the cor j porations and the assessors have gone into court j and secured orders adjusting the assessments i pursuant to the Court of Appeals decision

It Is impossible to obtain a record of the corporations which have paid their tax, or the amounts paid j because that is a transaction local to th taa j district In which each franchise operates, th duties of the State Tax Commissioners ceasing i when they have valued the franchises

Hay Once More Declines to Reopen Panama Question

Secretary Hay yester day sent another communication to General Ilafael Reyes, the Colombian Envoy, in response to his protest against the action of the United States regarding affairs on the Isthmus of Pan ama
While State Department officials decline to make any specific statement as to its nature

It is understood that, In a general way, it fol lows the lines laid down In the reply to Oeneral Rwyes's first note, which practically declined to reopen the Panama question, and also follows tho recent message of the President to Congress on the Panama question
Justifying the step taken by the United States government
The reply does not discuss one matter which General Reyes urged In his second note, the transmission to the Senate of the correspondence between himself and the State Department
It is known that the officials of the State Depart ment resented the suggestion of General Reyes as highly improper, and for this reason the an swer does not discuss this request
The matter of sending the correspondence with General Reyes to the Senate has not yet been deter mined by the President
The Bunding of the note to General Reyes yes terday prevented his contemplated trip to Bal timore for treatment by a specialist, for which he had made arrangements the day before

Gen eral Reyes's last note also contained soma ref erence to the submission of disputed points to arbitration, but State Department officials say that there is nothing in the present situation for The Hague tribunal, if any reference to that court were Intended
General Reyes la ready to leave the city at any time for Colombia, where his personal and political Interests require his attention
It was said to-night that he might leave this country within the next ten days, but no information waa obtainable from him, as he declined to see reporters, on the plea that he was very busy
From the standpoint of the State Department, there is no reason why he should hasten his departure, as he might very well remain and render considerable service to his country

Tha suggestion was made to-night that possibly he might stay and try to open diplomatic relations with Panama, through its representative here, for the adjustment of such questions as the as sumption by Panama of a part of the exterior debt of Colombia

Some suggestion also has been made, though not officially, of a reunion of the two govern ments under the name of the Republic of Co lombia, Panama to have an autonomous gov ernment, with absolute authority to deal with all questions relating- to the control of canal matters

Xot Hostile to This Country in the Far East

An authority c-nversant with Russia's position In the Far East, and her attitude toward American interests, made to-day the following statement In view of the wide circulation given reports without basis In fact, chargins Russia with hos tility to American Interests in the Far East, it seems expedient that the attitude of Russia should be again defined

Russia has repeatedly expressed her Intention of assisting tha development of commercial Inter ests In Manchuria, knowing that the Chinese policy of the United States government Is guided merely by an aim to djvelop tride and not by political ambition
Russia has shown her good faith by refraining from any action which would en danger the eonclu3lon of the American-Chinese commercial treaty signed on October S
That treaty has been ratified by the throne at F and thus, through the medium of tha United States, the important ports of Moukden and Antung
in Manchuria, are opened to the commerce of the world

This is the 'open door which ha been a part of American and Russian policy since the Boxer outrages, which necessitated the Interven tion of the powers, and which materially changed conditions in Manchuria
Russia will certainly not submit to dictaaon at the hands of any power as to the protection of her legitimate Interest in Manchuria

Petersburg and Peking Ln the effort to reach an agreement adequately pro tecting the special or predominant Inrtuence exer cised by Russia in Manchuria, and which has been recognized by all the powers signatory to the peace protocol verbally or In writing

At tha time ci the signing of that convention It waa Russia's hope that she could with safety with draw her forces from Manchuria last October, and leave the protection ut her interests to China, In 'ho nit time, however, it
was clearly demon strated that the guarantees offered by China were wholly Insufficient, and it became necessary for tr
e Russian government to ask for additional guar antees
Until these have been arranged for tha Russian goernment cannot be expected to with draw from Manchuria, and thus menace the many Russian livea and forfeit the 2
Russia Is ready and anxious to stimulate the de velopment of foreign commerce in Manchuria
The growth of trade means the success of the Siberian railway
Russia believes, however, that this com mercial development is possiole without the estab lishment of spheres of political influence irx ih open ports

Russia's political influence in this ter ritory, which lies in her borders, is and must 04 considered predominant, and its effectiveness would be lmpairea by the creation of any form of foreign political Influence in the shape of extra-territorial government or municipal control and regulation of certain districts within thaae open ports similar to conditions such as
But no trouble Is anticipated on this score, aj th American-Chinese commercial

treaty, providing for the setting aside of certain districts in Moukcien and Antung -b places of international residence and trade, and the provision for their regulation, is not considered aa tending toward the establishment of a system like that surrounding foreign interests at Shanghai
'Russia does not propo3 to discuss tha negotia tions now ln progress
It will be an Interesting bit of Information to the Russian government to know that tha primary ol- Ject of the Tokio negot'ations
so far as Japan is corcernpd
Is the protection of American ard Ens- Ush Interests ln the Far East

Criticism which was elicited by one feature of the electrical programme of the New- York Central Uaiiroad has just received attention from two well known technical periodicals, The Electrical World and Engineer and The Engineering Kecord
Some of these encourage the hop that this typo of current mny eventually prove serviceable, but it can hardly be siid that all of the minor questions Incident to its adoption have yet beon solved
Under tlie circumstances, tfce Central gave the preference to the direct current, ami now one occasionally hears the suggestion that when its motors are in actual use they will be obsolete
For their approval of the Central's choice tho technical Journals present two cogent reasons

In view of the immense amount of traffic to be handled and the vast Inconvenience which would result from a serious interruption, it Is better to eliminate all doubt and uncertainty at the outset Again, certain other railways notably that In the subway which the Central will make connections have decided to use the direct current
It is desirable, of course, to have the roiling stock so equipped that trains from one road ran be run over the tracks of the other and unnecessary changes of car by pMMBgon averted
To the general public these considerations will appeal so strongly that it Is safe to say that tho Central's decision will ex cite almost unanimous commendation
The pa trons of the road will unquestionably be better pleased to see a well tried system adopted soon than to be obliged to wait several years longer for the promised Innovation
It Is due to tho Central to remember that It has already displayed a distinctly progressive 6plrlt in 6evpral ways
The electric locomotives which are to haul Info the city Its great express trains will likewise represent the hitest advances In mechanism which hare stool the test of actual service
Besides, If the time ever comes when the Central deems it expedient to Introduce the alternating current, no orml daWe barrier to the change will exist

13 An incident which came near having serious results, which were averted by the prompt intervention of L'nited States Minister Powell, took place here on the arrival of the Clyde Line steamer New-York

Powell persisted in his demand, saying that the government had no right tro take such ac tion, and that the President must hand the let ters to him, which President Morales reluctant ly did

Powell also told President Morales that the agent was entitled tn his protection, as he represented an American company that he Minister Powc-I would not consent to this arbitrary act on the part of the government, and that, further, the agent could not be ex pelled, as was threatened

A remarkable tale comes from Oklahoma about village rivalry with tragic results

Would Raise 8,, a Year for CanahThh City Affected

Discussion by legislators during the present week of the probable method of taxation which will be employed to raise the money necessary to build the new barge carial has disclosed a rather striking unanimity of opinion that at lenst one measure which the Governor had in his mind at the time he sent his message to the legislature was a record tax on mortgages

The assertion was made at the Capitol this week by a person entirely familiar with the subject of taxation that it was the gen eral impression in Haw-York City among those who had given the matter careful thought that the Governor's plan when it was finally made public would be purely and simply this, the tax being in all probability five mills
Such a tax would raise approximately 3,, annually, the sum which, it will be remembered, the Gov ernor believed sauld be necessary for the first two years

It will he recoiled that in his last message Governor OdJl called the attention of the legis lature to the subject of a mortgage tax, and aid, with what was believed at the time to be of considerable significance Much of the assessment in New-York City is occasioned by taxation upon mortgages, which should not ext
ni jli n bn t'r treatment of this class of personal property in its contribution to the expends of government fir would tend to minimize the unjust proportion cf payment of taxes
In two previous messages Governor Odell has dealt with the question of a, mortgage tax
an 1 has recommended the abolition of the direct tax and a one and two mill record tax
but it is the opinion of those who are best Informed on the subject that the abolition la a matter which requires several years more of education for the public
ThU opinion was expressed only the other day by a New- York City oAetal whose ideas carry weight in this matter

The prevailing notion is that both in his reference In the message and In his two previous recommendations of a more di rect character the Governor foreshadowed the line of action that he believes the legislature should take in raising the 101,
The minimum sum raised annually by such a tax la estimated at dBOQiIi That this may be too low an es timate, and that the Governor has been able to figure a larger income, is also suggested

The burden of this tax, as, indeed, of any tax for the canal, would fall on New-York City, and it has been reasoned that there will be a con siderable effort made to defeat such a measure, although, of course, until the matter la definitely known, no action can even be conjectured
The question of when this important measure would be Introduced has naturally occasioned more or less guessing
It was said at the Capitol yesterday, with some show of credibility, that whatever measure was Introduced to meet this necessity would not make Its appearance before the middle of February

Philip of Orleans Revoked Petition at Emperor's Request
The Allgemeine Zeitung says that Duke Philip of Orleans is seeking a divorce, and that, he has petitioned the Curia for a dispensation to enable him to marry the daughter of a great Austrian noble

The All gemeine Zeitung asserts that the duke con sulted the leading members of the Royalist party last summer and Informed them of his intentions, giving as a renson that his present union was childless and that he desired to con tinue the royal line

The Royalists endeavored to dissuade the duke from taking the action be proposed, and pointed out to him that his divorce end remarriage would scandalize Cath olic circles in France, the chief supporters of the Royalist cause

Investigation In well Informed circles shows that it was the duke's intention to obtain a divorce from the arebducheaa, but that through the personal intervention of Emperor Francis Josopll the differences of the couple were ad justed, the duke withdrawing his petition to the Curia
The wootaa whom the duke desired to marry is said to be the Princess Clementine, daughter of Pauline, Princess de Metternlch-Sandor
The archduchess has repeatedly tried to induce the duke to live as a more consistent claimant to the throne of France

Pressure on Porte to 'Allow Black Sea Fleet's Passage

That Russia has applied to Turkey for permission to send her Black Sea fleet through the Dardanelles is confirmed authoritatively here, and it is also asserted that Russia will renew the application and press for Turkish consent
Germany's attitude, un changed from the time the four unarmed Rus sian torpedo boat destroyers passed through the straits in September, 1002, 13 that she has no concern in the matter
The British government Is believed here to have identified itself more fully week by week with the Japanese position, until now Great Britain is almost as deeply committed as Japan

The position In which Great Britain now stands, according to the view taken of the situation here, brought about by public opinion and by the feeling that Russia would yield If only a firm altitude were shown, has impressed and Is Impressing the Russian statesmen
The readiness with which the United States associated herself with Japan In pressing for the signature of the commercial treaties with H ajrei rVlt'ntrinutvii fittif in'fit
The decision for war or peace now rests with the Czar's advisers, and symptoms are visi ble here that the decision will be peace, by large ly admitting Japan's demands
The views of the British editors, partially de rived from the Foreign Office in London, are looked upon hero not only as significant, but as part of a great diplomatic game against Russia
The skill Japan has shown through the negotia tions excites admiration at the German Foreign Office
The report published in the United States by a r
ews agency to the effect that the British government had informed Japan that any attempt of tae Russian Black Sea fleet to pass the Dardanelles would be checked by de cisive action is untrue

Lord Lansdowne to-day, however, expressed disbelief that Russia had any intention of trying to send a fleet through the Dardanelles, adding that it would be an ob vious breach of treaty in which Great Britain could not possibly acquiesce

By the Treaty 0 London, signed in 1841 by the five great powers of Europe nnd by Turkey, the Sultan was pledged to maintain the rule of the Ottoman Empire which prohibited the warships of any foreign power from entering the Dardanelles while Turkey was at peace, and, at the same time, the treaty bound the powers to observe this rule
This was confirmed by the Treaty of Paris In 1556 and by the Convention of IS7I
At the Berlin Congress on the Eastern question, in 1878
the Russian plenipotentiaries Insisted, in reply to a statement mad by Lord Salisbury, that

the principle of the closing of the straits Is a European principle, and that the exist ing stipulations are binding on all th powers, not only as regards the Sultan, but as regards all the powers signatory to these transactions
The Treaty of Berlin, ratified August 3
provided that tho Treaty of Paris of 1556 and the Treaty of London of 1S1 were maintained when not modified by the new treaty, thus continuing the enforcement of the rule

Japanese Statement of Points at Issue in Far East
A high Japanese authority to day made the following explanation of the status of the Far Eastern questiors The statement that Russia has made conces sions to Japan is not exact

Russia in the month of October made certain concessions, which were accepted by Japan, but subsequently withdrew them and assumed an attitude which left the Japanese little hope in the way of reaching a satisfactory agreement

The Japanese government, confident in the declarations of disinterestedness in Manchuria made by Russia, and recognizing Russia's spe cial interests in that region, wished to regulate, once for all, all questions in the Far East, in the interest of future peace and tranquillity
To this end Japan made the following proposals First Russia, and Japan should mutually respect the Independence and territorial integrity of China, and Corea
Japan the- spe cial interests of Russia in Manchuria Russia, the special interests of Japan in Corea
Third enae mutually not to Infringe
Japan the commercial rights and immunities acquired by Russia in Corea Russia, the commercial rights and Immunities acquired by Japan in Manchuria

In making the third proposition Japan wished not only to protect her own rights in China and those of Russia in Corea, but to consecrate by the principle of equality of treatment the com mercial rights of all nations in Corea and China

Russia declined the Japanese propositions and submitted a counter proposition, which con tained a clause providing for the creation of a neutral zone extending trom the Chlnese-Corean frontier to Wong-Tan, on the east and to Ping Yang on the west
This zone comprised almost a third of Corea

All to Quit if Power House Men, Non-Union, Work
Another subway tieup Is threatened unless by noon to-day non-union men employed by firms outside of New-York to put In the equip ment at the West Flfty-nlnth-st

There are five or six of these firms, the largest of which Is the Alis-Chalmer3 company, of Cleveland, which fought the last general strike of the Interna tional Association of Machinists throughout the country for the rine-hour workday for over a year

It culminate,, it was stated yesterday, by the unions in nearly a dozen skilled trades whose members are employed at the power house informing the com raptors for the subway who employed their members that If the non-union men were not discharged before noon to-day work rt the power house would he tied up and the strike extended to all the subway

The suggestion of The New- York Tribune to refer the Ru3so-Jap' sst WaV culty to the Hague Tribunal has been widely re produced

the Petit Jourr-il and in the leading papers of the departments the idea, on the whole, comes as a welcome solution in the present pacific tendency of th Gallic spirit, for everywhere, except among a few redhot Nationalists, any notion of France being drawn into active intervention is dreaded as an awful calamity

Nevertheless, moderate patriotic organs, such a the Temps and the Journal dcs Debnta refrain from urg ing France's great and beloved ally, the Emperor of Russia, to take the initiative, and The Trib une's suggestion, is published without comment
The true gist of French opinion is set forth in the conversation I had to-day with the French apostle of arbitration and the French delegate to th Hague Tribunal, Baron d'Estournelles de Constant
Deputy of the Sarthe, who made the following statement We must not expect too much from the Hague Court
Its creation is still recent, and yet last year and the year before all the European pow ers, France included, were more or less hostile lo the court and tried to boycott it

It Is only the prudent initiative of the United States that has saved the Hague Court from that tacit hostile coalition, but President Roosevelt, in do ing so when ha sent before the court the case of the Pious Fund of California, took great care to choose that case among the small and merely financial foreign difficulties of his government
He would never have begun with a big polittcal affair, and if another government had advised him to follow a different line he would have certainly refused to li
It is the same with Russia
for Russia un doubtedly considers her difference with Japan a3 a national one
K it before th Hague Court, but if Russia is
not prepared to go to The Hasrue she cannot forget the Hague Convention, which may give to her, as well as to Japan, important facilities, for the settlement of their conflict
it has been de cided by Article thav every civilized power is morally bound to offer her bons offices
Very likely England has already offered her bons of fices to Japan, and it may be that France, In accordance with the universal pacific feeling of opinion, has tendered the same to her ally
Let us lgin, as President Roosevelt has done, with small cases
when consulted on the subject, declined to express an opinion, considering the matter, In view of the French alliance with Russia, too delicate for France to take the initiative In such a proposal

A SERVICE PENSION BILL To Be Introduced in Congress with President's Approval
A service pension bill will be introduced in the Senate to-morrow by Mr
Dolliver, of lowa, and In the House by Mr
Calderhead, of Kansas, when the House meets again on Monday

The bill is backed by the Grand Army of the Republic and if enacted into law will give a pension of 12 a month to every soldier who served ninety days in the Union Army in the Civil War, who was honor ably discharged therefrom, and who has attained the age of sixty-two years
A like pension will be given to tbe widows of such soldiers in all casts whre the marriage took place before June 27, 1890
The Introduction of the bill Is the result of the meeting In Washington of the committee on pensions of the Grand Army
They also talked with Pension Commissioner Ware about their work

The bill, it is explained, is not designed to in terfere with existing pension legislation and It provide in terms that no soldier or widow re ceiving a pension under Us provisions shall be entitled to a pension under any other law

but it brings to us as members of Congress new questions and new responsibilities, and I take It to be a great privilege to be a member of the House or the Senate at this time in our country's development The necessity of new markets and better commercial facilities was felt by the people long before it appeared In government policies

The construction of an Isthmian canal transcends In importance any other act of legislation or diplomacy to which the government can commit itself, and the peo ple will look impatiently, In my opinion, at any individual OT political party that seeks to em barrass this work with partisan outcries

If this session of Congress accomplishes nothing els- than to render possible the Immediate con struction of the canal across the isthmus, it will have done enough to entitle it to a hisch place in the list of useful and memorable ses sions
